snippet.title: Tablets expected to become preferred computing device
snippet.description: Forrester Research expects sales to hit 375 million by 2016, with 760 million in use by that year.

snippet.title: Dragon NaturallySpeaking Preferred 9
snippet.description: For people who type a lot or suffer sore fingers and hands, Dragon NaturallySpeaking 9 is the best tool available for dictating text and commanding a Web browser by voice, despite the gradual adjustments needed to conform to your personal manner of speaking.

snippet.title: Dragon NaturallySpeaking 7.0 Preferred
snippet.description: With near-perfect accuracy and expanded software support, Dragon NaturallySpeaking 7.0 takes the prize as the best personal speech-recognition software.

snippet.title: Mac OS X 10.5.3: Airport stops automatically connecting to preferred network
snippet.description: Mac OS X 10.5.3: Airport stops automatically connecting to preferred network

snippet.title: The TV preferred by four out of five evil geniuses
Women prefer Apple, gentlemen prefer Samsung
snippet.description: In a study looking at which mobile brands are preferred by the sexes in America, the results are perhaps predictable. However, a ray of hope for MicroNokia is that almost 25 percent of people expressed no preference.

snippet.title: HTC may dish Ice Cream Sandwich to Flyer tablet
snippet.description: Just weeks after deploying Android 3.2 to the 7-inch tablet, HTC is rumored to be ready for 4.0 Ice Cream Sandwich.

snippet.title: Prioritize wireless networks to maintain your connection
snippet.description: If your Mac's Wi-Fi connection is constantly changing to one you cannot access, a quick system preferences adjustment could do the trick.

snippet.title: 8 Google Reader alternatives for your PC
snippet.description: Google Reader will be shut down as of July 1, but never fear. Here are eight desktop and laptop alternatives to keep track of your favorite Web site updates.

snippet.title: Google, Nielsen deepen ties for ad ratings on YouTube
snippet.description: Google has extended a deal with Nielsen to provide "online campaign ratings" for ads on YouTube -- the Web's biggest video platform -- after testing out such a relationship since November.
